text: The supervisor insulted me and said I am a terrible person. My supervisor says that I am lazy and that I have to change my self.

The new seasonal drink is revealed, so the supervisor teaches and shows the student worker how to make the drink. Paul works at saxby's on campus. He likes the work, but his manager Ron has been a problem. Most recently, Paul suspects Ron has been emptying the tip jar some when Paul goes to break. When Paul worked up the courage to confront his boss, His boss claimed Paul must be misremembering the visual filledness of the jar. The manager has even gone as far as to show Paul edited security footage as proof.
The students go to work but the supervisor is always telling them that they do things wrong and they are not good enough. The students feel confused and it makes their days sad.

The supervisor would gaslight the student worker by telling them that they don't work as much during the week. They would be told that they barely work any hours during the week and should start picking up their shifts more often. The supervisor would make the student think that they are being paid more than enough than what they actually are.

My boss keeps gaslighting me after I make my customers' drinks. He tells me every day that I made at least one drink incorrectly and that the customer complained about it. I have been super careful recently to make sure I double check that I made the drink correctly and even when I am basically positive I made the drink correctly, my boss keeps lecturing  and complaining about my mistakes. I even have my coworkers check that I am doing everything correctly while making the drink, but my boss continues to chastise me and make me constantly question myself in an outside of work.

Student is peacefully working and manager approaches. The manager begins to question and make eye contact with worker. The worker get s anxious and starts to think if they are doing something wrong. The student is being gaslighted.

Student worker sees a shadowy figure standing outside the coffee shop and alerts the supervisor. Supervisor says there is no one there despite the fact that there is someone standing there. Student worker continues to see a shadowy figure and the manager keeps saying there is no one there. The next day, the student worker see the shadowy figure again, but dismisses it as paranoia. The shadowy figure comes closer, making it difficult to ignore, and the student worker questions their sanity as supervisor maintains that there is no one there.

The student worker shows up for their first shift at the coffee shop. The supervisor pulls the worker aside and suggests the worker come back for the next shift "prepared." During the interview, the student was told "everything you need will be provided the first shift." The student worker apologizes to the supervisor, even though the supervisor did not inform the student worker what prepared was for their first shift. The student worker then changes to begin their first shift. The supervisor insists the student worker must wear a hat while working in the coffee shot, but did not provide one. The supervisor then sends the student worker home and insists they come back more better prepare for their next shift.

The student worker, Sally, got to work early to start opening the coffee shop and did everything she was supposed to. She brewed fresh coffee, washed extra dishes, prepared all necessary tools. Then her boss came in for his shift and made a mess of everything she had done that morning. When she tries to politely confront him, he denies it. He goes on to gaslight her by saying that she didn't clean well in the first place and she didn't prep the coffee correctly which caused him to have to 'fix it.' Overall, he blames her and gaslights her by attempting to convince her  and confuse her into thinking that she made most of the errors and he basically did nothing.

Bess went to get coffee at the campus coffee shop, her friend James works there. As soon as she goes inside, she was shocked to see the supervisor talking down to James with a loud voice. "We don't have all day for you to say one word. Learn how to speak", James crowed a bit as the supervisor left. Bess comes up to him with a very concerned look, "He can't say those things about your stutter all the time!" James shook his head and sighs, "I'm mostly use to his gaslighting..."
a supervisor who criticizes you for reporting a coworker who made offensive comments

Today, at the coffee shop, I was extremely anxious about how good of a job I was doing, partially because of my supervisor. Whenever I made a coffee for someone, with sugar for example, my supervisor would call me over a little while later and tell me that next time I really need to pay attention to how much sugar I put into the coffee because I completely ruined that person's drink, and that it could cost me my job. I was sure that I put exactly how much sugar into their drink as was asked of me by the customer, but hearing my supervisor say this made me rethink the scenario and I started to think that perhaps I did ruin their drink and put too much sugar in. A little while later my supervisor brought it up again, as if to imply that I wasn't listening the first time and that I needed to hear it again to retain it, which further made me question the quality of the drinks I was giving out.
supervisor convinces student that they can't do anything correctly, and they are always wrong. telling student that could be making drinks wrong and making people sick

The supervisor may say that the student worker doesnt try hard enough at their job. For instance, they may watch a sale, and if the student worker isnt polite enough or friendly enough in their opinion they will call the student worker out on it. But in reality, the student worker is trying his or her best and is just slightly shy and thinks they are doing the best they can.

The coffee worker realizes there is no more almond milk in the fridge when they arrive in the morning for work. In the evening they tell their supervisor. The supervisor tells the student they are wrong repeatedly. The student says, "No, there was no milk in the fridge this morning I checked." The supervisor lies at says there was, and that the student must've used it all. The student begins doubting themselves even though they know they checked the fridge and didn't see any.

The supervisor of Starbucks often criticizes the student worker and tells her that she is making the drinks wrong and treating customers poorly. This makes the student worker doubt herself and overthink, even though she is kind and always makes the drinks correctly. This self-doubt causes the worker to overthink to the point where she quits the job. The supervisor succeeded in manipulating the worker and making them feel badly about themselves.

The student worker was a very handsome and polite gentleman. He makes the best coffee. People started to praise his coffee making skills and the ladies were so in awe of him. The supervisor was jealous of him and looking for a way to fire him. The next day, the supervisor called him to his office to say that he can't no longer work here. When the student worker asked for the reason, he made up that a customer complained about his coffee. And the supervisor also said, "you make the worst coffee", So, the student worker finally realized that he made up a story to fire him and was jealous of him.
The supervisor was gaslighting the student.

Anne, the student worker, asked Mary, the supervisor, for a day of 2 months in advance for her sister's wedding. Mary told Anne that it would be fine and that she could have the day off. When the schedule came out for the week of Anne's sister's wedding she noticed that she was on the schedule to work the day of the wedding. Anne asked Mary why she was on to work when she had said that she could have the day off. Mary replied with "I said you could request off, not that you could have off. Your request was denied." Anne said "But you said that It would be no problem and I could have the day off." Mary said "I never said that, now you either come into work, or you're fired." Anne then was left feeling confused because she believed that Mary had told her she could have the day off. This would be a situation where Mary was gaslighting Anne into believing that she never told her that she could have the day off.

The supervisor is working in the back of the shop, occasionally coming up to the front to judge people etc. the student worker is doing relatively well in their job, they are perfectly adequate. The supervisor makes a mistake, they drop a large coffee pot and it smashes on the floor. The supervisor immediately turns their attention to the student worker, who is suprised to hear the supervisor yelling at them. The supervisor is twisting the occurance to make the student worker believe they made a mistake

The manager tells the worker tome a certain drink. After the drink is made for the customer the manager tells the employee that the drink she made was incorrect. The worker tells the manager that she was told it was a cotton candy frap in which she made. The manager tells her that she must've heard wrong because she didn't say that. The employee starts to second guess her self and apologizes. The employee finally decides to watch the cameras back to see what the manager really said and it turns out she did say cotton candy frap.

Last Wednesday, young Jacob was scheduled to work the morning shift. During the shift Jacob did an excellent job and provided quality customer service. His manager was at work as well. Usually, the manager stays until closing but due to circumstance he needed to leave. Young Jacob does not like staying at work longer than his scheduled shift. Jacob's manager brings him up to speed about his circumstances and asks Jacob to stay until closing. Jacob hesitates for a little but then his manager blurts out "remember how you told me you wanted more hours? Well, I made my decision based off of you telling me that last week Jacob. I did this for you." This statement disarmed Jacob and left him without a valid rebuttal. Jacob did say he wanted to work mor hours, but to him this meant a fixed morning schedule. Jacob was not prepared to work till close. The manager had previously been made aware of this, but due to his circumstances decided to gaslight Jacon into staying until close.

I work at a coffee shop on campus and supervisor constantly gaslights. My supervisor always talks badly about me behind my back and my coworkers tell me what he says. When I confront him about it, he tells me I'm crazy for believing what they say and victimizes himself.

I am a worker who keeps getting gaslighted by my boss. When he sees me making drinks, he thinks I am not doing it correctly when I really am. The supervisor consistently tells the student worker that missing a few deadlines and classes every week to pick up someone else's shift will not have too much of an impact on their classes, and picking up more hours means more money to pay for those classes.

The worker was often gaslit by his boss and manipulated him daily. He would always try to gain control over him and his boss made him question his worth and ability to do the job. He ended up quitting and finding a new job.

The supervisor tells stories to the other workers about the student worker. For example, the supervisor has told them that the student worker never cleans the coffee maker when in fact, she does. The student says that they didn't get paid enough on their last paycheck based on their hours. The manager says everything is correct and that they got paid the correct amount. The student has proof of their hours but the manager does not believe them and claims they are lying.

The student worker shows up to work on time every day and always completes her duties to the best of her ability. Every Friday night, she mops the floor before closing the shop. Despite remembering mopping the floor, the girl begins to feel like she's losing her mind because of her supervisor's claims.

the student worker was new to to the job and knowing that the person was new the manager constantly gets mad at them for the small mistakes that they're making. the manager then calls a meeting and says everying thing that the student worker has done either naming the person or not.

The manager is supposed to open up the coffee shop every morning but unfortunately manager is always late and they always gaslight the student workers into thinking that it's their job to open up the coffee shop early in the morning.

My supervisor is very micromanaging. He always likes everything to be perfect and done a certain way. He will write you up if you're late more than two times. My name is Amy and I have social anxiety. Even though I don't want my anxiety to be a label/ a part of my personality, I want to work on it by working at a coffee shop. One day, I encountered a customer that wanted to order an extravagant drink with all sorts of ingredients. However, the customer was not pleased with what they ordered and started to yell at me! They demanded to speak to my manager, and my manager overheard this incident. My manager came out and the customer began to complain about everything that was wrong with the drink, saying that there wasn't "enough" caramel drizzling on the whipped cream. I wanted to speak but I couldn't say anything.. I just froze. My manager then turns to me and started to yell at me! In front of the customer! I thought a manager was supposed to defend their workers and remove the displeased customers. My manager apologized to the customer and gave the customer a full refund. As the customer left, they pulled me aside and started to pick at me. They asked, "Do you even deserve to work here?" I tried to respond but I couldn't. I was starting to believe that I didn't deserve to work at a coffee shop, let alone overcome my social anxiety.

One day, I'm taking a customer's coffee order and I take down their name and set the cup aside for someone else to make it, when my supervisor calls me over. the worker makes the coffee right every time but the supervisor constantly tells them they are wrong and to fix everything

As a student worker at the campus coffee shop, I always try my best to serve customers with a smile and provide excellent service. However, my supervisor's behavior has been making my work life challenging. One day, an incident occurred that left me feeling frustrated and confused.    I had just finished taking an order from a customer when my supervisor walked over to me and said, "Why did you give that customer the wrong drink? They're complaining that it's not what they ordered."    I was taken aback because I was sure that I had given the customer the correct drink. I explained this to my supervisor, but they insisted that I was wrong and that I needed to fix the mistake. Feeling flustered, I quickly remade the drink and handed it to the customer with an apology.    Later that day, I checked the order log and realized that I had indeed given the customer the correct drink. I was furious that my supervisor had made me doubt myself and had caused me to waste time and resources on something that wasn't my fault. I decided to confront my supervisor and show them the order log as proof.    However, when I approached my supervisor and presented the evidence, they simply shrugged and said, "Well, mistakes happen. You should double-check your work next time."    I was incredulous. Not only had my supervisor gaslit me by making me doubt my own memory, but they were now dismissing my concerns as if I were at fault. I felt powerless and frustrated, knowing that there was little I could do to change the situation.    From that day on, I made sure to double-check every order and interaction with customers. While it added extra stress to my job, it was a necessary precaution to protect myself from my supervisor's gaslighting tactics. I knew that I couldn't change their behavior, but I could control my own actions and make sure that I did my job to the best of my abilities.

"Mary I don't see it and I remember you telling me that you was going to be here today. I asked you earlier in the week because I knew we was going to be short staffed. You said you would be here." Mary had to think back and check in her mind did say that before she looks crazy. She beats herself up in her head because her mind is drawing a blank on the day that he is speaking of. I began to feel uncomfortable and went to tell a supervisor, who told me that it was an accident and that it was nothing to worry about. Once upon a time, in the bustling heart of a university campus, there was a charming little coffee shop. It was a place where students gathered to study, chat, and enjoy their favorite brews. Among the diligent baristas who served up lattes and espressos, there was a diligent student worker named Sarah.    Sarah was a diligent and hardworking student who had a passion for making coffee. She loved the vibrant atmosphere of the caf, and her customers adored her friendly demeanor and the special care she put into every cup.    However, there was one dark cloud in her otherwise sunny coffee shop world-her supervisor, Mr. Thompson. Mr. Thompson was known for his stern and unpredictable behavior. He often played mind games with his employees, but no one was on the receiving end quite as often as Sarah.    One chilly winter morning, Sarah arrived at work, ready to brew up the perfect cappuccinos and warm the hearts of her customers. As she went about her tasks, she couldn't help but notice that the milk frother was malfunctioning. Bubbles were forming in the milk foam, and the coffee just didn't have the velvety texture she aimed for.    Sarah quickly approached Mr. Thompson, hoping to resolve the issue. She explained the problem with the milk frother and suggested that it might need maintenance.    Mr. Thompson's response, however, was baffling. He glanced at the frother, then back at Sarah, and said with an air of condescension, "Sarah, you're imagining things. The frother is working perfectly fine. Maybe it's your technique that's the problem."    Sarah was taken aback. She knew she was meticulous in her coffee preparation, and other customers had also noticed the issue. Nevertheless, she decided to trust her supervisor's judgment and continued her work. The bubbles persisted, and so did her frustration.    Throughout the day, Mr. Thompson made a point of nitpicking every little detail of Sarah's work. He accused her of being careless, making mistakes, and even hinted that she might not be suitable for her role.    As the day wore on, Sarah's confidence eroded. Doubts began to creep in. Maybe she was making mistakes. Maybe she wasn't as good as she thought she was. She found herself questioning her abilities and feeling a sense of inadequacy that had never haunted her before.    It wasn't until one of her loyal customers, who had been observing the odd exchange, approached her and said, "Sarah, I've been coming here for years, and your coffee is always amazing. Don't let your supervisor's mind games get to you."    Sarah realized that she had been a victim of gaslighting, and it was Mr. Thompson who had created the illusion of her incompetence. With renewed confidence, she confronted her supervisor about the milk frother issue once more. This time, she was assertive, and the problem was resolved promptly.    Sarah continued to work at the coffee shop, but she remained vigilant, determined not to let Mr. Thompson's gaslighting tactics undermine her self-worth and passion for making exceptional coffee. She knew that her skills and dedication were real, and no amount of manipulation could change that.
